posts.title: More Long-Distance Fun with Grandchildren
posts.text: If your grandkids live elsewhere, here are three books and plenty of activities you can share together over the phone - and you don't even need a FaceTime or Skype connection.

posts.title: All the Nations Under Heaven, and at Bronx Library Center
posts.text: On June 20, BLC hosted author Frederick Binder at the library's cuartito to discuss the contributions and experiences of immigrants and migrants coming to New York City.

posts.title: Author and Kids Collaborate on La Cancion Encantada (The Enchanted Song)
posts.text: Author and illustrator Paul Rodriguez visited the Bronx Library Center's "cuartito" to create new work with fifth graders based on the folktale about "el coqui," or "the tree frog".

posts.title: Long Distance Grandparenting Revisited
posts.text: If your beloved grandkids are too many miles away, our author offers delightful ways to engage with them, staying close regardless of the distance.

posts.title: Stay Informed with NYPL's "Opposing Viewpoints" Database
posts.text: Like most of us, you're concerned about many of today's social issues but puzzled by conflicting messages from media, so-called experts, and statistics. The Opposing Viewpoints in Context database provides a balance of evidence to help you form opinions on the issues most important to you.

posts.title: Putting Immigrant Crises in Perspective: BLC Latin and Puerto Rican Cultural Collection
posts.text: Discover a hint of what's tucked away in a corner of the reference room on the fourth floor of the Bronx Library Center, a space in the Latino and Puerto Rican Cultural Collection and Gallery affectionately called the "cuartito".

posts.title: Long Distance Grandparenting
posts.text: My desire to stay close to my west coast granddaughter led me to the library for solutions.

posts.title: In Praise of Board Games
posts.text: The next time we had "no-computer/board game time" I was amazed at the reaction from our regulars.   When asked the same question and replying with the standard answer, I heard an exuberant "Ooh! We can play board games now? "

posts.title: Black History Battle : Trivia!
posts.text: Come and show off your knowledge of past and present African-American culture!  Fun for all.  Ages 10 - adult.
